channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: Covid Live Updates: C.D.C. Says All Adults ‘Should’ Get Booster Shots
item.description: South African scientists who first identified Omicron caution against panic. A federal judge temporarily blocked a vaccine mandate for health care workers in some states.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Travelers wearing personal protective equipment arrive at Sydney International Airport in Australia, on Monday.

item.title: As World Shuts Borders to Stop Omicron, Japan Offers a Cautionary Tale
item.description: Japan, which has been very cautious throughout the pandemic, is again barring all nonresident foreigners. There is an economic and human cost.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Sensoji shrine in Tokyo, which has typically been a top destination for foreign tourists.

item.title: Xiomara Castro Vows New Era for Honduras but Is Tied to Past
item.description: Xiomara Castro, headed toward becoming her country’s next president, promises to expunge its legacy of corruption, but change may be tempered by her establishment ties and conservative opposition.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Joan Suazo
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Xiomara Castro during her presidential election campaign in Honduras this month.

item.title: After the Floods, British Columbia Picks Up the Pieces
item.description: Washed-out roads and destroyed bridges are just some of the devastation afflicting residents of the western province and could signal what climate change will bring in the future.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: A truck damaged in recent flooding last week in Merritt, British Columbia.

item.title: Iran Insists on Immediate Lifting of Sanctions as Nuclear Talks Resume
item.description: After five months, negotiations on restoring the 2015 nuclear deal with Iran resumed in Vienna, but with a harder line from the new Iranian government.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: Iran’s chief nuclear negotiator, Ali Bagheri Kani, arrives for a meeting of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action in Vienna, Austria, on Monday.

item.title: She Fled North Korea for Freedom. Then She Was Arrested.
item.description: The case of “Chrysanthemum” offers a rare look at the covert battle the rival Koreas are waging over North Korean defectors living in the South.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Ministry of State Security of the People's Republic of China
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A photograph of Song Chun-son, who is in prison on espionage charges, being displayed by her sister, Song Chun-nyo.

item.title: Sweden Elects Its First Female Leader — for Second Time in a Week
item.description: The Swedish Parliament elected Magdalena Andersson as prime minister by a narrow margin. She was first elected last week, but her government soon collapsed over a budget dispute.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Christina Anderson
item.media:credit: Jonas Ekstromer/TT News. via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Magdalena Andersson in Stockholm on Monday after she became Sweden’s prime minister.

item.title: In a Nonbinary Pronoun, France Sees a U.S. Attack on the Republic
item.description: When a French dictionary included the gender-nonspecific “iel” for the first time, a virulent reaction erupted over “wokisme” exported from American universities.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Léontine Gallois
item.category: Le Petit Robert de la Langue Francaise (Book)
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: France is particularly on edge over the rise of American gender and race politics. Many politicians and academics believe their language and nation are under attack from the United States.

item.title: Will the Covid Vaccines Stop Omicron? Scientists Are Racing to Find Out.
item.description: A “Frankenstein mix” of mutations raises concerns, but the variant may remain vulnerable to current vaccines. If not, revisions will be necessary.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: A woman received her second Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine dose from a health care worker in Katlehong, east of Johannesburg, in South Africa.

item.title: As U.S. Hunts for Chinese Spies, University Scientists Warn of Backlash
item.description: A chilling effect has taken hold on American campuses, contributing to an outflow of academic talent that may hurt the United States while benefiting Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:credit: An Rong Xu for The New York Times
item.media:description: The campus of Princeton University, in New Jersey. Chinese and Chinese American scientists working in U.S. universities have been disproportionately targeted by the U.S. government.

item.title: Hunt for the ‘Blood Diamond of Batteries’ Impedes Green Energy Push
item.description: Dangerous mining conditions plague Congo, home to the world’s largest supply of cobalt, a key ingredient in electric cars. A leadership battle threatens reforms.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey, Eric Lipton and Ashley Gilbertson
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The foreman of a mining crew that is digging for cobalt in Kasulo.

item.title: A ‘Simpsons’ Episode Lampooned Chinese Censorship. In Hong Kong, It Vanished.
item.description: The episode mocked both Mao Zedong and the government’s efforts to suppress memory of the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang

item.title: Climate Change Driving Some Albatrosses to ‘Divorce,’ Study Finds
item.description: Warming oceans are sending the monogamous sea birds farther afield to find food, putting stress on their breeding and prompting some to ditch their partners.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Martin Zwick/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A colony of black-browed albatrosses in the Falkland Islands. Albatrosses usually mate for life.

item.title: ‘You’re Not Helpless’: For London Women, Learning to Fight Builds Confidence
item.description: After a year marked by isolation, loneliness and violence in the city, many self-defense and martial arts gyms say they are seeing more interest from women.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Muay Thai class at Fightzone London.

item.title: World Omicron Fight Hindered by Fragmented Response
item.description: Almost two years into the pandemic, finger-pointing, lack of coordination, sparse information and fear are once again influencing policy.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: A ticket counter at the O.R. Tambo International Airport in Johannesburg on Monday.

item.title: Biden Military Review Leaves Troops Where They Are, for Now
item.description: The report sidesteps a decision on what to do about troop numbers in Somalia, after President Donald J. Trump’s decision to pull out last year.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden visited troops at Fort Bragg in Fayetteville, N.C., last week.

item.title: Letter From Catherine the Great Shows Her Support for Inoculations
item.description: In a letter from 1787 to be sold at auction this week, the Russian empress called for widespread access to a precursor of the smallpox vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: A portrait of Catherine the Great by Dmitry Levitsky will be auctioned alongside the letter in which she extols the virtues of variolation, an early inoculation process.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Confronting the Omicron variant.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: Staff members stand at the departure gate of Tokyo's Haneda international airport on Monday, as Japan announced plans to bar all new foreign travelers over the Omicron variant.

item.title: South Africa Officials See 'No Red Flags Yet' on Omicron Variant
item.description: Officials said that while they need more data to be sure, existing treatments and precautions seem to be effective against the Omicron variant.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Testing for the coronavirus in Johannesburg on Saturday.

item.title: UK Announces Omicron Cases and Extends Boosters to All Adults
item.description: The British government was widely criticized for a sluggish response to the Delta variant, and its reaction to Omicron came markedly quicker.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Commuters in London on Monday. The government will mandate masks on public transportation and in stores.

item.title: Dutch Police Arrest a Couple Who Fled Quarantine and Boarded a Plane.
item.description: One of the pair tested positive for the coronavirus after they arrived on a flight from South Africa. They were quarantined at a hotel.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: The hotel in the Netherlands where some passengers who arrived on flights from South Africa are in quarantine after testing positive for the coronavirus.

item.title: Czech President Appoints Prime Minister From Inside a Cube
item.description: President Milos Zeman tested positive for the coronavirus on Thursday and went into isolation, delaying the ceremony for three days.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: Czech President Milos Zeman, right, separated with a transparent wall after testing positive for the coronavirus, appoints Petr Fiala as Czech Prime Minister at the Lany Manor house, near Prague, Czech Republic on Sunday.

item.title: Scotland finds 6 cases of Omicron, but no sign its spread is ‘sustained.’
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Nicola Sturgeon, Scotland’s first minister, described the emergence of Omicron as the “most challenging development of the pandemic for quite some time.”

item.title: Portugal Detects 13 Omicron Cases Tied to Belenenses Soccer Team
item.description: The team, Belenenses, took part in a game that had to be abandoned after a Covid outbreak reduced the number of eligible players. One infected player had recently returned from South Africa.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:description: A soccer game in Portugal between Belenenses and Benfica over the weekend was abandoned after a virus outbreak. It was later revealed that some of those cases were of the Omicron variant.

item.title: The Latest on Omicron
item.description: What should you assume about the new variant?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A crowd in London this weekend.

item.title: Meet the Beauty Queens of Al Dhafra
item.description: Camel beauty contests take center stage at a celebration of Bedouin culture, held annually in the United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: Kiki Streitberger
item.media:description: Pert ears? Check. Long droopy lips? Check. A nose ring? Check. Expressive eyes framed by upward curled eyelashes? Check.

item.title: Taliban and 9/11 Families Fight for Billions in Frozen Afghan Funds
item.description: The White House must figure out what to do with the Afghan central bank’s account at the Federal Reserve, now blocked under U.S. law.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taliban spokesman Zabihullah Mujahid, announcing the new Taliban government of Afghanistan at a press conference in Kabul in September.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Omicron moves across the world.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Passengers wearing protective gear arrive at Incheon International Airport, in South Korea on Sunday.

item.title: A Woman is Charged With Arson in Queensland Quarantine Hotel Fire
item.description: A 31-year-old mother and her two children had arrived in Queensland a few days ago.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: The Pacific Hotel in Cairns, Australia, caught fire Sunday morning. Its 163 occupants were evacuated safely.

item.title: Both parties claim victory as Honduras awaits election results.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Voters wait for their ballots at a polling station in Tegucigalpa.

item.title: Snowstorm Leaves Dozens Stranded for Days in a Remote U.K. Pub
item.description: A crowd had gathered on Friday night to listen to Noasis, an Oasis tribute band. On Monday, most of them were finally able to go home.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat
item.media:description: Snow as high as three feet in some places blocked the exits of the Tan Hill Inn in northern England.

item.title: Omicron Variant Surfaces Amid an Airline Travel Rebound
item.description: With several countries imposing new restrictions, the question now is whether travelers will be deterred.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:description: Israel said on Sunday that it was sealing its borders to all foreigners for 14 days after one case of the new coronavirus variant was confirmed in the country.

item.title: As China Speeds Up Nuclear Arms Race, the U.S. Wants to Talk
item.description: The Pentagon thinks Beijing may build 1,000 or more weapons by 2030. But it’s the new technologies that worry strategists.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and William J. Broad
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: China’s DF-17 hypersonic ballistic missiles have warheads that can zero in on targets at more than five times the speed of sound.

item.title: Covid Law in Switzerland Is Approved in a Vote
item.description: After weeks of heated debate and protests, voters backed using Covid certificates that are required to enter public spaces.
item.dc:creator: Noele Illien
item.media:description: Nearly two-thirds of Swiss voters elected to endorse the government’s Covid-19 laws.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: An update on the Omicron variant.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Health workers in the Netherlands transported passengers from South Africa to a hotel for quarantine.

item.title: When Will We Know Results in the Presidential Election in Honduras?
item.description: Polls began wrapping up around 5 p.m. with few reports of problems so far.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: A polling place in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, on Sunday.

item.title: U.S. Health Officials Push Vaccines as Omicrom Spreads
item.description: Getting a vaccination remains the best line of defense against Covid-19, the nation’s top two health leaders said on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:description: President Biden has urged more people to get vaccinated against the coronavirus, as the world faces a new variant. He was in Nantucket, Mass., with his family for Thanksgiving on Friday, above.

item.title: Japan, Israel and Morocco Impose Bans on Foreign Travelers; Australia Delays Reopening
item.description: Israel and Morocco have also barred all visitors from overseas, as countries race to respond to the threat of the Omicron variant.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Staff members at the departure gate of Tokyo’s Haneda international airport on Monday, as Japan announced plans to bar all new foreign travelers over the Omicron variant.

item.title: Hondurans seek a break from graft and despair in an election with repercussions for the United States.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev

item.title: South Africa Is Better Vaccinated Than Most African Countries
item.description: The country has one of Africa’s better vaccination rates: Just under one-quarter of its population has been fully inoculated.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: A health worker greeted people at a vaccine pop-up center in August, in East Rand, South Africa, as part of a measure to help the government speed up the inoculation campaign in the country’s remote communities.

item.title: The Netherlands finds at least 13 Omicron cases and expects more.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Sem van der Wal/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Dutch health officials reported that of 61 passengers on two flights from South Africa on Friday who tested positive for the coronavirus, at least 13 were infected with the Omicron variant.

item.title: A Wine Rack on Rails? U.K. Businesses Seek Solutions to Shortages.
item.description: Two months after concerns about gas and food stocks caused ripples of anxiety, Britain continues to face problems in its supply chain. Distributors and retailers are looking for creative fixes.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A freight train being loaded with nearly 650,000 bottles of wine at Tilbury Docks, east of London.

item.title: Scotland Detects 6 Omicron Cases as Britain Weighs Booster Expansion
item.description: The Scottish cases come after Britain announced three cases of the new variant over the weekend and as the British health secretary urged people to get a booster shot if they were eligible.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Aaron Chown/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Sajid Javid, Britain’s health secretary, on Sunday.

item.title: Portugal Soccer Match Abandoned After Covid Reduces Team to 9
item.description: Players from the Belenenses team criticized sporting officials for demanding the match go on, saying soccer had “lost its heart.”
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:description: Belenenses players, right, during a huddle before the match.

item.title: What’s at Stake in the Honduran Presidential Election?
item.description: Hondurans head to the polls on Sunday, but widespread political violence during the campaign and questionable results from 2017 are looming large.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.media:description: Vendors selling political party flags in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, on Friday, ahead of Sunday’s national elections, which may be the most significant in a decade.

item.title: The W.H.O. Skips Forward Two Greek Letters, Avoiding a Xi Variant
item.description: Under the World Health Organization’s system, the Omicron variant might have been called Nu or Xi, but only at the risk of ambiguity or diplomatic awkwardness.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: Collecting a swab from Bronwen Cook for a PCR test for the coronavirus before a flight to London, at O.R. Tambo International Airport in Johannesburg on Friday.

item.title: Laszlo Z. Bito, Scientist, Novelist and Philanthropist, Dies at 87
item.description: He fled communist rule in Hungary, discovered a treatment for glaucoma in the U.S., then became an author and a voice against authoritarianism in his homeland.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg

item.title: A Tale of Culinary Reconciliation, Beside the Eiffel Tower
item.description: Two decades ago, Spain was the new France, leading gastronomic innovation. Now two iconic chefs have joined forces in Paris.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Spanish chef Albert Adrià, second from right, and the French chef Alain Ducasse, right, at their pop-up restaurant ADMO in Paris, along with the pastry chef Jessica Préalpato and Vincent Chaperon, the cellar master of Dom Pérignon.

item.title: How did Omicron get its name?
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:description: Tulio de Oliveira at the Nelson Mandela School of Medicine in Durban, South Africa, last week. Mr. de Oliveira and members of his team announced the new Covid-19 variant.

item.title: A Couple’s Dream of Reuniting in England Is Dashed in a Channel Disaster
item.description: A young Kurdish woman, Maryam Nuri, died with 26 others after making a desperate attempt to join her fiancé by crossing the English Channel from France on an inflatable boat.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: As Omicron Variant Circles the Globe, African Nations Face Blame and Bans
item.description: With countries trying to close their doors to the new coronavirus variant, southern African officials note that the West’s hoarding of vaccines helped create their struggle in the first place.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller and Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Travelers checking a flight information board at Johannesburg’s international airport on Saturday. Many countries have banned travelers from southern Africa since the discovery of a new variant.

item.title: U.K. Confirms Two Cases of Omicron Coronavirus Variant
item.description: The prime minister reimposed a mask mandate, saying ‘there are many things we just cannot know.’
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan and Isabella Grullón Paz

item.title: As Potential Omicron Variant Cases Emerge, an International Scramble to Shut It Out
item.description: Dutch health authorities say it’s likely the Omicron variant will be detected among 61 infected travelers from South Africa.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Social Media Photo Obtained By Reuters
item.media:description: Passengers awaiting Covid test results in Amsterdam’s Schiphol Airport, in an image shared on social media on Saturday.

item.title: They Twice Gave Up Everything to Flee Iraq. They Keep Getting Sent Back.
item.description: Bria Ali and her family have twice tried to make it to Germany, desperate for a better life. They are now back home with thousands of others who made it to Europe in recent months only to be deported.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Hawre Khalid for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bria Ali at her home in Erbil, Iraq, this month. Bria and her family were deported from Poland on Oct. 31 after crossing the Belarusian border.

item.title: How Did the New Covid Variant, Omicron, Get Its Name?
item.description: The World Health Organization began naming the variants after Greek letters to avoid public confusion and stigma.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:description: Tulio de Oliveira at the Nelson Mandela School of Medicine in Durban, South Africa. Mr. de Oliveira and members of his team announced the new Covid-19 variant.

item.title: Germany Finds Suspected Omicron Variant Case
item.description: A couple returning from South Africa are Germany’s first confirmed Omicron cases. Italy confirmed a case in a traveler returning from Mozambique.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Travelers arriving at the airport in Munich on Saturday.
